title: How many Arab League member states other than Palestine will diplomatically recognize the State of Israel as of 28 August 2021?

“In order to neutralize the soft war measures of the Zionist enemy, the Islamic Resistance must activate its capacities in this field, while maintaining and strengthening the cohesion of the Resistance forces, exposing the political, security and social realities of the Zionist regime to the world,” Iran’s top security official suggested.  The emergence of GCC-Israel relations in a changing Middle East - Brookings Institution
https://www.brookings.edu/research/the-emergence-of-gcc-israel-relations-in-a-changing-middle-east/
Wed, 28 Jul 2021 07:00:00 GMT > In contrast, the UAE views Israel as a formidable regional power that shares these views and is willing to act forcibly to counter regional adversaries. A formal alliance with Israel, therefore, makes strategic sense. So, while the normalization agreements were billed by the Trump administration, which brokered them, as peace accords, they were clearly driven by coalition-building rather than peacebuilding. > Moreover, amid the threat posed by the spread of popular uprisings in the region, the Gulf states have become eager purchasers of sophisticated surveillance technology in order to more effectively police their populations.[13] For its part, Israel has been a willing purveyor of this technology with few reservations for possible human rights abuse.[14] This has given a corollary benefit to their relationship and offered new commercial pathways that have dovetailed with the UAE’s own ambitions of becoming a regional technology and innovation hub. Moreover, since normalization, the sides have announced a number of areas of commercial cooperation, including plans for an oil pipeline running from the Red Sea to the Mediterranean.[15] But most significant of all, the Saudi-UAE axis views a closer relationship with Israel as an indirect means of preserving its partnership with Washington. This motivation is largely shared across the GCC because of the importance of the decades-old American-backed security architecture in the region. However, in recent years the Gulf states have had ample reason for concern about America’s long-term commitment. In particular, lengthy and costly American wars have generated fatigue at home with continued military engagement in the Middle East. And while energy security was once the bonding agent of the U.S.-Gulf alliance, a resurgence in American energy production over the past decade has created the perception of it coming unglued. As a result of these and other factors, successive U.S. administrations have signaled a desire to modify, and perhaps reduce, America’s posture and presence in the region—a sentiment that may only deepen as a result of the economic costs of the COVID-19 pandemic.[16] For the Gulf states, however, which are highly anxious about the regional outlook, retaining America’s commitment to their security is paramount.[17]  Moreover, Israel and the Gulf axis have found common cause in trying to steer America’s Middle East policy in a mutually beneficial direction.[22] In particular, the two sides viewed the Obama administration’s pursuit of a nuclear agreement with Iran, and subsequently an end to Iranian isolation, as troubling and dangerous. Finding ways to counter the Obama administration’s agenda became an opportunity for the two sides to work together without U.S. involvement—a significant step in the development of this relationship—and the eventual basis for working with the incoming Trump administration in 2017.[23]  In fact, an early test to the resilience of these normalization agreements came in April and May 2021, when widespread Palestinian protests in Jerusalem during the holy month of Ramadan were violently dispersed by Israeli security forces, including harrowing raids on the Al-Aqsa Mosque compound—one of Islam’s most sacred sites—during the holiest month of the year, in which Israeli forces launched stun grenades and tear gas into the mosque itself. The subsequent bombing of the Gaza Strip by Israel, in which dozens of children were killed, and communal violence between Jews and Arabs in Israeli cities added to the pressure. While the events were unlikely to lead to backtracking on a long-term strategic decision like normalization, they clearly made the normalizing states uncomfortable, produced a backlash from within their societies, and demonstrated that without an end to Palestinian subjugation such uprisings will reoccur and continue to test the Gulf-Israel relationship.[30] Ted Cruz blocks bill advancing Israel-Arab normalization in spat over language - The Times of Israel
https://www.timesofisrael.com/ted-cruz-blocks-bill-advancing-israel-arab-normalization-in-spat-over-language/

Israel is in the middle of a (albeit fragile) ceasefire with Hamas. The Israeli foreign minister Yair Lapid is due for an official visit to Morocco in July. Therefore, calm prevails in the short term with the latest Arab League country not receding from the initial agreement to develop links between the two countries and the closing date is near. https://www.reuters.com/world/middle-east/israels-fm-lapid-says-will-travel-morocco-late-july-2021-07-19/

I count six current: Egypt, Jordan, UAE, Sudan, Bahrain, and Morocco. Reserving a 1% chance that one of those falls away.

Even though the normalisation of diplomatic channels between Israel and Morocco has stalled somewhat in 2021 with the resultant lack of ambassadors, embassies, or open liaison offices, there have been significant signs of some semblance of diplomatic recognition.
King Mohammed VI, who is the highest authority in Morocco in both State and religious aspects, congratulated the new Prime Minister of Israel, Naftali Bennett on his election.
Morocco’s main policy goal is to gain international recognition for its sovereignty over Western Sahara that was gained from Trump’s government as a prerequisite for normalising relations with Israel.
The Israeli carrier Israir is commencing flights between Tel Aviv and Marrakesh in July 2021.
Therefore, contrary to my previous argument, I will suggest (and concede) that Morocco is the sixth country to recognise Israel albeit sans consular facilities and given the overriding authority of the King.  https://www.reuters.com/world/middle-east/hamas-chief-meets-party-leaders-morocco-visit-2021-06-17/
https://www.reuters.com/world/middle-east/israeli-carrier-israir-start-flights-morocco-july-2021-06-01/

Increasing my probability slightly in the second to last bucket per details in this comment: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1288521

Presently there are five Arab League states that have recognised the State of Israel which are Bahrain, Egypt, Jordan, Sudan and the UAE in some part to counter the threat that Iran represents.
The sixth state expected to add to these was Oman.
However, Oman prefers to remain a relationship with Iran that a recognition of Israel would harm.
The recent conflict in Gaza and the condemnation from the Arab League of Israel concerning the plight of the Palestinians has halted any further recognition in the immediate future.
Saudi foreign minister Prince Faisal bin Farhan stated that ‘the kingdom “categorically rejects the Israeli violations against Palestinians”, while calling for an immediate ceasefire’.
The remote chance of Saudi Arabia recognising Israel as a bulwark to Iran is now more remote.
A recent meeting of Muslim Nations concerning the Gaza conflict, criticized not only Israel but those Arab League countries who now recognised it. https://www.mei.edu/publications/oman-plays-it-safe-israel  https://www.un.org/unispal/document/resolutions-adopted-by-the-league-of-arab-states-at-its-155th-extraordinary-session-held-in-cairo-on-3-march-2021/  https://www.reuters.com/world/middle-east/arab-league-chief-condemns-israeli-air-strikes-gaza-2021-05-11/  https://apnews.com/article/world-news-israel-europe-middle-east-summits-7add3e4ddb4d52cc704acde8dcb1a650
Coming at this without much info.  Agree with @rpmiller4 that withdrawal costs more and is unlikely.  I'd maybe put 1% on "less than 6" if it was a single category

The 2020 normalizations were somewhat transactional (unsure if this is the norm): Morocco, recognition of its sovereignty over Western Sahara; Bahrain, continued U.S. support; UAE, Israel suspended West Bank annexation plans in exchange for the U.S reversal of its position on the legality of settlements; Sudan was removed from the U.S. State Sponsor of Terrorism list. If Israel escalates activity in Gaza and the West Bank and the (Arab) World pressures denormalization would any of these countries actually reverse their position?  Surely Netanyahu wants to keep all these agreements intact and has calculated whether or not they are at risk by attacking Gaza. Also, I think the cost and backlash for recognizing Israel have already been incurred, and it's more costly in all respects for these countries to reverse their recognition of Israel at this point.

I'm still very confident that the fundamental Realpolitik dynamics are changed with the recent Gaza attacks, but I'm tweaking my forecast slightly New articles Can Israel blast Gaza and still make friends in the Gulf? - Reuters
https://www.reuters.com/world/middle-east/can-israel-blast-gaza-still-make-friends-gulf-2021-05-17/

I currently count 6: Bahrain, Egypt, Jordan, Morocco, Sudan, UAE. Mauritania has withdrawn recognition, so these decisions aren't permanent. With the violence that's recently started in Jerusalem, it's possible things could revert backwards. Example: https://www.jpost.com/middle-east/jordan-warns-israel-against-barbaric-attacks-on-mosque-statement-667671

For a member of the Arab League to recognize Israel as a state is a weighty political decision. Upon some research, a few Arab League members cited the treatment of Palestinians as a hesitation towards recognizing Israel as a state. As of May 2021, Israel could see new leadership (which could be more hospitable towards Palestinians), which may allow room for some countries to reconsider their current stance.

I note that CoupCast gives a 4% chance to a coup in Sudan in a year (https://www.oneearthfuture.org/activities/coup-cast), giving a ~1% chance of a coup before question resolution. In case of a coup, Sudan would probably stop relationships with history. This is not 100% yet.
With the Biden administration no other countries would recognize Israel.
Consensus of the crowd since a lot of months

With the Biden inauguration, there will be less diplomatic pressure and less diplomatic incentives offered to Arab league states to normalise relations (i.e. like US recognition of the Western Sahara that was offered to Morocco).
May decrease given US now cutting off some military items to Saudi and UAE
2 full diplomatic relations and 4 more in 2020

The 22 members of the Arab League as of 2018 were Algeria, Bahrain, Comoros, Djibouti, Egypt, Iraq, Jordan, Kuwait, Lebanon, Libya, Mauritania, Morocco, Oman, Palestine, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Somalia, Sudan, Syria, Tunisia, the United Arab Emirates and Yemen.

Yamina's falling poll numbers reduce the probability of annexation of parts of the west bank after the Israeli election during this timescale, and therefore reduce the chances of an unwinding of positive relations between Israel and the Arab countries.  Furthermore, the threat from Iran that unites them shows no signs of abating. In fact, like North Korea is, Iran will probably further escalate tensions in order to use the following detente as a false-concession in the upcoming negotiation with America's new representatives. And indeed, the Arabs and Iraelis are likely to feel even less secure with the new Biden administration, especially if a nuclear deal is agreed that does not cover Iran's ballistic missile programme or proxy warfare, as all this will do is give Iran even more money to pour into these.
SA and Qatar calling it truce. This place is healing, unbelievable last 12 months for this region. Money will flow. I want to go to 100% deep down.
Various options for the 6th / 7th as of end-Dec 2020 Possible that some may wait to see Biden's interactions with Israel during H1'2021
Paying credence to the crowd's certainty

Morocco just announced, making 6. Leaving 1% in each other category on the possibility that relationships deteriorate by August as the region can be volatile. https://apnews.com/article/donald-trump-africa-israel-north-africa-morocco-4279242f6f688d242bad5c7a64e29caf?utm_medium=AP&utm_source=Facebook&utm_campaign=SocialFlow&fbclid=IwAR0Z_p0v1IpQUKp_6KYWutyDPB-I08GC5N1CSyPczKwh9Xyp4JqebCsQb5s

+10 to follow the crowd a little, and recent signs seem to show there could be at least a few more recognizing Israel in the coming months. Leaving a small percent on lower numbers in the event of some kind of conflict or breakdown of relations.

At present, 5 Arab League members (Bahrain, Egypt, Jordan, Sudan, and UAE) recognize Israel.  There are reports of a recent meeting between Israel and SA (https://www.businessinsider.com/us-arranged-israel-saudi-meeting-as-reward-for-assassination-sources-2020-11), but that meeting was publicly denied by SA and no formal recognition resulted for now.  Pundits believe that SA recognition is not possible under King Salman, but may be under his successor, MBS.  The Trump administration made Arab recognition of Israel a key part of its foreign policy, but his failed reelection bid leaves the future of the recent momentum up in the air.  I suspect many Arab states will wait to see how a new Biden administration approaches the subject.  Still there is plenty of time before the question closes out, for at least one more Arab League member to recognize Israel.
I'm personally closer to 60%, but I'm deferring heavily to the aggregate here.
Numerous reports out re Bibi meet Salman in Saudi.

Under pressure to recognize Israel, says Imran - Times of India
https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/world/pakistan/under-pressure-to-recognize-israel-says-imran/articleshow/79256022.cms
Tue, 17 Nov 2020 04:35:00 GMT No change

Any of Oman, Mauritania, or Saudi Arabia could be the 6th. Also possible relations deteriorate under a less Israel-friendly Biden, but I don't think Biden would want to reverse course on this positive development. Still lots of time left in the question as well. +15 to 6 or more.
Maybe a 5% that Sudan stops recognizing Israel.

President Biden cannot ignore the suffering of the palestinian people as his "friend" Bernard puts it which means he will demand unrealistic stuff from Israel, also he will bring "qualified" people into it and kick out the "unprofessional" people who did those deals under Trump.
Biden must feel the pressure to continue this, to make it a US effort and success, not a Trump one.

Downgrading as Trump victory is looking less likely with Biden surging in Michigan. Also on a country by country basis, it's not obvious who is next after Sudan (maybe Oman?). Nonetheless, there are 19 candidates and a lot of time.

No significant rumors, and I'd expect that diplomatic initiatives would work differently after a Biden win (for one, I'd expect Mike Pompeo, who is reportedly thinking of running for president, to stop being Secretary of State). Further, Sudan was pretty desperate to get off the terror list, so coercing the country into recognizing Israel seems like scrapping the bottom of the barrel. Still, there is a long time to go until the question resolution.

I did not expect Sudan to be the next state, so I'm pushing much more heavily towards 6 or more. At the same time, I don't think I've seen significant rumors/reports of Oman, Morocco, Mauritania, or Saudi moving forward with formal recognition.

After Sudan to bet it stays at 5, you’re betting that the remaining 19 states don’t do an agreement. Haven’t done a state by state analysis, but basic probability suggests at least one more will follow.
Did not expect Sudan to be one of the earliest nations at all.
Sudan looks like it's in the bag

Anyone know where a reliable source is running this number as it happens? Who is the authority? We all see the information leak of potential recognition over the last few weeks, yet there hasn't always been a formal process for the reveal, so who is the authority on this for us to monitor?  Surely not twitter as has been the case for the last week. https://twitter.com/netanyahu/status/1319269344501641216?s=21
Updating given Trump's tweet about Sudan.  Could prompt other countries to change positions.

UN ambassador: Another country will recognize Israel in ‘day or two’ 
Headline proved to be false.
Bahrain, UAE, Jordan, Egypt already. Two more should be possible in a year.

Historically an Arab state recognizing Israel has been rare (Jordan - 1994, and Egypt 1979); however, given the Trump administration's push, momentum has increased significantly with the UAE and Bahrain recognizing Israel within the past month. President Trump announced that the administration is in talks with another 5/6 countries, reportedly Sudan, Oman, Kuwait, Morocco, and Saudi Arabia.  Saudi Arabia would be unlikely to recognize Israel in the near future if King Salman's health remains stable, but it's possible by next year. The U.S. elections may have an impact on this question since Biden has historically backed a two-state solution, but he may support, but he also said he supported the recent recognitions. https://www.nytimes.com/2020/09/27/world/middleeast/sudan-us-israel-peace-recognize.html
https://www.nbcnews.com/news/world/bahrain-becomes-second-arab-nation-recognize-israel-less-month-n1239894

https://www.i24news.tv/en/news/international/americas/1599287697-biden-says-he-supports-nations-recognizing-israel-even-if-palestinians-lose-leverage
Modifying forecast. Sudan and Morocco also in play
We are at 4 already with Bahrain. With the tensions va Iran, not hard to imagine one more of the GCC (like Oman or Kuwait but probably not Saudi) recognizing Israel. Very small chance of backtrack

By my count, we've got 4 states so far: Egypt, Jordan, UAE, Bahrain Very small chance (4%) that we go backwards due to some sort of backlash, possibly involving a 3rd Intifada
Fairly small chance (17%) that there is no further movement 
Moderate chance (31%) that there is one further state (maybe Oman or Morocco)
Moderate chance (48%) of 6+. This could be 2+ relatively unaligned states (e.g. Oman, Morocco, Mauritania) or I think is Saudi Arabia does recognize Israel (though there seems to be conflict between the king and MBS on this point), they'll bring at least one other state with them.

Bahrain already recognized Israel. Oman, Sudan, Morocco are likely to follow suit as are Saudi Arabia and Mauritania, but diplomatic negotiations tend to be slow and are easily put on hold, so one year might not be sufficient time to finalize many of them officially. https://www.economist.com/middle-east-and-africa/2020/09/19/the-arab-israeli-conflict-is-fading?frsc=dg%7Ce

I found this to be a good background article. Also interesting how this could be tied to who’s running Saudi and USA next year...  thought I was being optimistic but see I’m not far off crowd forecast of 10; 40; 50 in top three buckets.
https://www.economist.com/middle-east-and-africa/2020/09/19/the-arab-israeli-conflict-is-fading?frsc=dg%7Ce
Using the current consensus as a prior, answering to put skin in the game

The logjam has been broken by the UAE and followed by Bahrain. Iran as a threat, could be the motivator. https://atalayar.com/en/content/arab-league-countries-view-israel-emirates-agreement
https://www.economist.com/middle-east-and-africa/2020/08/20/the-arab-countries-most-likely-to-recognise-israel
Oops forgot to count Bahrain. That makes 4 now with Oman possibly next.
Four are now, none are likely to drop out and there is every indication that more will follow

https://www.reuters.com/article/us-israel-gulf-usa/white-house-says-five-more-countries-seriously-considering-israel-deals-idUSKBN26906G
Orange House says maybe five more, including three "in the region."  The problem for us is that truth does not routinely reside there, at least not comfortably  The Leader Of The Free World says Saudi Arabia is a likely, which means we should probably scrub Saudi Arabia from the list even though he sometimes accidentally says something true.  Oman is plausible, though.    Moving up on the higher numbers because this initiative is actually a Good Idea and likely to be further pursued by whichever Olde White Guy wins the election.  Since the Q runs until August, there is plenty of time for more states to sign up if it seems to be going well.

Sounds like Oman, Mauritania, and Saudi Arabia are the most likely candidates. Trump also says more are likely, though I regard his claims with a big dose of skepticism. Many others are publicly saying it won't happen without a Palestinian state. The time frame on the question is long, so it's possible an Israel-Palestine deal could happen, but I consider it very unlikely. It's also possible that within the long time frame other countries come around to normalizing ties with Israel without a Palestine deal. Overall it seems most likely that they get to at least 6, and if not 6 then 5. But leaving 2 through 4 with some probability because it's possible relations break down again over the long question period or no further progress is made. https://www.middleeasteye.net/news/israel-normalisation-arab-countries-who-next-trump

Ultimately, the previous recognition was a surprise. I'm not sure whether I would be able to recognize whether a state was about to recognize Israel, because I didn't see it coming last time.  I.e., I'm relying less on warning shots and more on "how many countries have expressed favorable views about recognition".

I’ve never known Trump to exaggerate and per Economist:
“Bahrain and the United Arab Emirates signed an agreement to normalise relations with Israel. In a ceremony at the White House President Donald Trump said that “five or six” other Arab nations, which he did not name, are close to following suit. Palestinean leaders, whose would-be country remains under Israeli occupation, would rather they didn’t.” I am struggling with other countries. I keep seeing Saudi tipped but find that one challenging. Oman? Have also seen attempts by Sudan to come in from the cold? Time for a rethink on my part. I thought this would be a one-off but people seem tired of Palestinian issue and want to move on. Plus carrots like F35’s (previously blocked).
Bahrain has signaled intention but not done so so currently three, but likely to be four. Trump is talkin about seven or eight but with no time-scale.
UAE, Bahrain are obviously a lock.  Jordan and Oman will want to get on board for economic reasons.

Egypt, Jordan, UAE and Bahrain are likely to recognize Israel at that time - so at least four. The next most likely are Sudan and Saudi Arabia, both of which have been making moves towards Israel in recent weeks, so if this continues at least one of them is likely to recognize Israel and it could be both. Possibly, other Arab league countries e.g. Oman, Morocco could also follow.
Maybe we all will be surprised. It's economy and a mixture of interests.
Wow, I did not see that coming.

Oman will be next. It is possible that events will change things between now and 28/08/2021 such that Saudi Arabia also signs an agreement, which is pretty much a prerequisite for Yemen or Kuwait to join. After that Sudan could join but it's not relevant to the question.
+15 to 6 or more on Bahrain news.
Bahrain now too. Surprised it was this quick https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2020/09/israel-bahrain-agree-establish-full-diplomatic-ties-200911171014685.html
Bahrain has stepped up. If Trump is buying Israeli recognition, we are probably going past 6, then possible back down to 3 or less by August 2021.
Things accelerating? Bahrain almost in, saudi seems having close friends prepare the ground

https://www.reuters.com/article/us-israel-bahrain-usa/bahrain-follows-emirates-in-normalizing-ties-with-israel-idUSKBN26226T
that's four so far, so bumping up the odds on five, because why not?

Trump has just announced that Bahrain has officially recognized Israel. It massively increases the chances of Saudi Arabia normalizing its relationship with Israel due to its closeness with Bahrain. Morocco and Oman were already very likely to follow, even more so now. Total is now at 4. Expected this to happen but not this quickly!

Ok see I was wrong not to count Egypt, Jordan and UAE. I was locked out of GJO from Sept 3-9 so did not see Sept. 2nd notice though. Saudi Arabia says not without a Palestinian state. Arabs tend to follow them. Bahrain might do it or Oman might do it. Possibly Sudan. Can not see the damn breaking without Saudi approval though.
It may take a bit for Saudi to formalise its new friends

It's unlikely there will be a small shift diplomatic stance from any individual nation in the next year. It's been reported by the NY Times that the UAE's change in stance was the result of a chance meeting between Bibi and a senior diplomat at a restaurant in Washington over 2 years ago (one of "The Daily"'s podcasts eps in the last 2-4 weeks). But, if any nations do shift in their stance, I would believe it will happen as a block rather than in drips and drabs.

Most likely will be 3 because as mentioned by people, things move slow in this game. I just think if the Saudi's join the party then it's likely to be 6 or more because of their influence on other AL States.

It looks like the recent UAE deal is starting to have an influence within the Arab League as per the below, not really sure on the reliability but this was interesting: [Quote]
The sources told Lebanese Al-Mayadeen news channel that Bahrain has rejected a request filed by Palestine to hold an emergency meeting of the Arab League to reject the Israeli-Emirati normalisation agreement which was agreed in mid-August. “Bahrain has also rejected the Palestinian request to place a clause rejecting normalisation on the sidelines of the League’s regular session,” the sources said, stressing that “Bahrain has threatened Palestine that it would put a clause on its part to support normalisation and encourage the deal of the century,” in reference to Trump’s ‘peace deal’. [/Quote] Looks like there is softening from within the Arab League, which will likely cause the split that most have spoke about - Iran/Saudi. The answer to this question depends on the reasons as to why the Arab League States would diplomatically recognise Israel after 70+ years of antagonism over the formation of the State and their support of Palestinians.
Pragmatism has become a common thread that join certain Arab League Nations in their concern (fear) over the intentions and actions of Iran together with friendly relations with the U.S. together with Israel’s technological edge in fields when compared with the Arab League.
Therefore, the number of member states most likely to recognise Israel by 28 August 2021 would be probably 4. https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-15747941 https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-53805828  https://www.trtworld.com/opinion/qatar-s-iran-policy-is-pragmatic-not-idealistic-38841
